body: @criccomini do you know what these "beeline" failures are in the mysql tests? I have PRs failing due to them as well.
No idea. :(

When the DAG is parsed and the scheduler figures out that a task instance needs to run, it's placed into the `SCHEDULED` state. Only tasks in the `SCHEDULED` state get sent to the executor. Once the task gets sent to the executor, it's placed into the `QUEUED` state. Since only tasks in the `SCHEDULED` state get sent to the executor, it eliminates the problem of the same task getting sent to the executor multiple times.
Is the queued state set by the executor or by the scheduler? (Reading from phone)
It's set by the scheduler.
FYI.. this was actually merged.. but was left open for some reason so I am closing it.
@normster please include screen shots! It easier to add the screen shots here than to Jira.
Ok LGTM, I do think some bits need to be ironed out but we can figure that out when it is in.

@jlowin, that should work. It is recommended way actually (http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/sqlelement.html#sqlalchemy.sql.expression.ColumnElement.is_). If this really cause problems, we can revert it.
@skudriashev @criccomini @mistercrunch @bolkedebruin please review. Most of the code change is for resolving pep8 warnings.

@skudriashev I agree it's definitely the right way to do it -- I just can't figure out why it isn't working for MySql (but fine for others). Maybe we aren't properly declaring that as a bool field in MySql terms? I'm scratching my head on this one.
@jlowin, aren't tests fine?

I don't think so -- all of the recent PR's Python 3.4 mysql tests have been failing. What's strange is that the error I pasted above doesn't actually seem to be failing a test -- it prints in the log of successful tests. I'm not sure it's being caught properly -- maybe SLA's are wrapped in a try/except.
@mistercrunch

Hello, I was wondering what the status was on this PR?  We recently started playing with Airflow at my company and ran into this exact use case (need one DAG to schedule another at a different `execution_date`).  @jeffreypicard, I'm happy to help and pick this up if needed.

Closing in favor of https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1685

@redundantsun Please follow the guidelines in https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide

Specifically, 
1. Open a Jira (eg. `AIRFLOW-XXX`) and preface your commit and PR with `[AIRFLOW-XXX]`
2. Assign the Jira to yourself
3. Set the "external_issue_url" in that JIRA to point to this PR - in other words, set it to `https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1702`

Once all of this is done, you can ping me here or on gitter.

I don't believe this change is warranted. A real production deployment of airflow requires a number of changes to airflow.cfg anyway (e.g. executor type, Fernet key, most likely a metadata db connection, etc) thus `load_examples` can be changed in production airflow.cfg as well if needed

I wonder if we can add some documentation of this feature in the Getting Started guide. I do find myself always disabling this feature. But, the reason this was set to True was for newbies and I don't want to lose that. I feel a reasonable compromise would be to add documentation to the Getting Started guide about turning this on for new users. Additionally, we can remove things that depend on Hive from the examples. That's definitely a no-no. While were on this topic, the test_druid.py dag needs to be moved out of the dag folder.. and moved into contrib/examples.

If accepted, this change needs to be made in both the dictionary AND the template. #1677 removes the dictionary config entirely. 

There is also a unit test that checks if `load_examples=True` that would need to be adjusted.
LGTM Thanks!

guys, plz review this.

@redundantsun sorry for the confusion -- if you look in `configuration.py` you'll see both a dictionary of defaults, the one you modified, and also a string template for `airflow.cfg`. You'll need to add your defaults in both places, preferably with comments in `airflow.cfg`. Also note that when you read the options, you'll want to use `getint()` instead of `get()` as appropriate, since they are stored as strings in airflow.cfg. Let me know if you have any questions!

@jalessio Even for small PRs such as these, for the purposes of generating nice release notes, we require you to follow the guidelines on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide

@r39132 - I sent a email requesting wiki write access to your Apache address, but pinging here in case you missed it.

One thing that I realized with the backfill is that if we create DAG runs, the current scheduler will pickup tasks and send them to the executor in this call:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/jobs.py#L892

To avoid that, we could check the state of the DAG run in that function and make sure that it's not a backfill.

Sorry to be joining the conversation so late. I've been testing the PR and as long as I have a scheduler running it works great. However, when there is no scheduler running, I get weird behavior: the backfill quickly iterates through all requested DagRuns and claims they are successful when in reality, the DagRuns aren't being created (they don't seem to be in the database) and the TaskInstances aren't either.

Update: maybe I'm doing something wrong, because now no matter what I do I get the above behavior (with the exception of the first DagRun, that one executes it's tasks correctly). Am I missing something?

```
# - delete airflow.db to start fresh
# - dev/airflow-pr work_local 1667 to clone PR
airflow initdb
airflow scheduler
airflow backfill example_bash_operator -s 2016-08-01 -e 2016-08-08
```

I don't think that Travis CI build is broken by this commit. It looks like build job # 3625.4 is failing for all recent PRs.

@d-lee rather than have to split the code for Py2/Py3, maybe just change `default_options.iteritems()` to `default_options.items()`, which will work in both versions? In this case I don't think there's any real benefit to using the lazy iterator in Py2 anyway.

I agree with @aoen, this will be very difficult to maintain. However, if you number everything as "1.", Markdown will automatically increment the numbers.

```

1. my 
1. auto
1. incremented
1. list
```

renders as:
1. my 
2. auto
3. incremented
4. list
